coredata.dc:description: Photocatalysis provides a promising opportunity for selective oxidation of biomass to high-value chemicals under mild conditions. The key to realize this transformation is to design a cost-effective and environmentally friendly photocatalyst. Here, we report the preparation of a carbon nitride photocatalyst with controllable carbon/nitride (C/N) ratio and its application in the selective photocatalytic synthesis of lactic acid from biomass-derived monosaccharides. Reasonable C/N ratio in the catalyst can significantly enhance the visible light absorption range and accelerate the mobility of photogenerated carriers. The obtained photocatalyst exhibited excellent photocatalytic activity, yielding 76.8% lactic acid. All of the h+,·O2 -,·OH and 1O2 are beneficial for lactic acid production, and the·O2 - plays a major role. Furthermore, the photocatalyst exhibited excellent reusability and universality. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Photocatalysis provides a promising opportunity for selective oxidation of biomass to high-value chemicals under mild conditions. The obtained photocatalyst exhibited excellent photocatalytic activity, yielding 76.8% lactic acid. All of the h+,·O2 -,·OH and 1O2 are beneficial for lactic acid production, and the·O2 - plays a major role. Furthermore, the photocatalyst exhibited excellent reusability and universality. The 1000-fold scale-up experiments indicated that the system has potential for industrial production of lactic acid. Therefore, the present work offers a promising example for photocatalytic reforming of biomass.

ce:section.ce:para: The use of solar energy has become a recent research focus. In particular, photocatalysis is studied as a promising method for utilizing solar energy [1–3]. The key to realize the photocatalytic process is to design a series of economical, efficient and environmentally friendly photocatalysts. As one of the most popular photocatalysts, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) has attracted extensive attention for decades and remains the focus of research [4–8]. In addition to strategies such as morphological control [9], senitization with dyes [10], hybridization with π-conjugated graphitic carbon materials [11] and coupling with other semiconductors [12] or conductors [13] to facilitate the visible light absorption and photogenerated electrons (e-)-holes (h+) separation, abundant attention has been paid to heteroatom doping to regulate the C/N ratio. This is because of the change in surface electron arrangement, which leads changes in the visible light absorption range and photogenerated carrier separation, thereby enhancing the substrate adsorption and activation as well as the photocatalytic activity. Thus far, however, only limited studies have been devoted to photocatalytic reforming of biomass to high-value chemicals via heteroatom-doped carbon nitride [4,5]. Similarly, in some biomass reforming processes, a wider absorption range of visible light is not the most important factor. Therefore, it is of great significance to reasonably control the C/N ratio in carbon nitride for efficient and selective photocatalytic biomass conversion.

Over the past decades, lactic acid production has shown great potential in food, beverage, pharmaceutical, cosmetic and chemical industries [14,15]. Currently, commercial lactic acid is produced mainly by fermentation of carbohydrates [16]. However, most of these processes have several drawbacks such as slow reaction kinetics, high nutrient cost, low space-time yield and complicated post-processing [17,18]. For these reasons, the synthesis of lactic acid by chemical methods has attracted wide attention. Therefore, homogeneous and heterogeneous catalyses have been reported in the synthesis of lactic acid, accompanied by a series of different catalysts. For example, a series of alkalis and soluble metal salts was used as homogeneous catalysts for the synthesis of lactic acid [19,20]. Although these processes have achieved good yields, inevitable shortcomings include corrosion in the catalyst equipment and difficult recovery. Correspondingly, heterogeneous catalysts have been proposed to overcome these problems. Accordingly, a large number of heterogeneous catalysts, e.g., γ-Al2O3 [15,21], Sn-Beta [22,23], Pt/C [18], ZrO2 [24], LaCoO3 [25], NiO/CaO [26] and UiO-66 (AA) [27], have been reported for the synthesis of lactic acid. Unfortunately, most of heterogeneous catalysis processes have low yields, high pressure, high reaction temperature and long reaction time, which are inconsistent with the requirements of green chemistry development. Therefore, construction of an economical, efficient and environmentally friendly catalyst for the synthesis of lactic acid under mild conditions is of great significance.

Photocatalysis, with merits of high efficiency, environmental friendliness and mild reaction, has shown great potential in the synthesis of lactic acid. In our previous works, an alkaline CuO-chitosan hybrid hydrogel (CuO@CS-H) was prepared at low cost for photocatalytic synthesis of lactic acid [3]. The CuO@CS-H not only retains the bandgap of the CuO but also improves its stability, resulting in enhanced photocatalytic activity. Interestingly, the basicity of the CuO@CS-H photocatalyst itself reduces the alkali concentration of the reaction system [3]. Furthermore, the alkaline CuO@CS-H photocatalyst has universality for different biomass-based monosaccharides in lower alkaline systems and shows conversions of rhamnose, xylose, fructose, mannose, glucose and arabinose at 91.2%, 100.0%, 99.0%, 96.2%, 98.2% and 98.1%, respectively; correspondingly, their yields are shown to be 85.7%, 81.6%, 67.8%, 55.6%, 54.2% and 52.7%, respectively [3]. To further reduce the production costs, oxygen atoms doped on the ultrathin porous carbon nitride (Ut-OCN) [5] and functional B@mCN from the doping of boron and oxygen atoms in the framework of g-C3N4 [4] were successively developed with low production costs for photocatalytic synthesis of lactic acid from biomass-derived pentoses and hexoses. Both of these catalysts exhibited excellent recycling stability and universality as well as high efficiency for the synthesis of lactic acid. The results of a 1000-fold scale-up experiment to produce lactic acid indicated that these systems have potential for industrial production. According to the above studies, the obtained novel photocatalysts all showed that the extended visible-light adsorption range is beneficial to the synthesis of lactic acid. However, whether a wider visible light absorption range relates to a higher yield of lactic acid has not been reported.

In the present study, a series of functional carbon nitride photocatalysts with a reasonable regulation of C/N ratio was developed and used in the photocatalytic reforming of biomass-derived monosaccharides to lactic acid. The effects of different C/N ratios on the synthesis of lactic acid were revealed by comparative experiments. The reusability and stability of the obtained photocatalyst, as well as the university of this system, were carefully investigated. The effects of h+,·O2 -,·OH and 1O2 on the photocatalytic-reforming of xylose to lactic acid were also explored. Furthermore, a 1000-fold scale-up experiment was used to verify the potential of this system for the industrial production of lactic acid.

All reagents and chemicals were used directly without further purification. Glucose (C6H12O6, 96%), xylose (C5H10O5, ≥ 99%), arabinose (C5H10O5, 98%), fructose (C6H12O6, 99%), rhamnose (C6H12O5·H2O, 99%), mannose (C6H12O6, 99%), ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (C10H16N2O8, 99.5%), tryptophan (C11H12N2O2, 98%), p-benzoquinone (C6H4O2, 98%), and isopropyl (C3H8O, ≥ 99.9%) were provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Melamine (C3H6N6, 99.0%) and choline chloride (C5H14ClNO, 99.0%) were obtained from Aladdin Industrial Corp. Acetic acid (CH3COOH, 99.8%), potassium hydroxide (KOH, 95%), formic acid (CH2O2, 99%), lactic acid (C3H6O3, 90%) and other reagents were bought from Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China).

Typically, 10 g of melamine and 1.0 g of choline chloride were added in 50 mL of ultrapure water in a 250 mL beaker upon magnetic stirring. The mixed system was stirred for 10 min and then dried at 60 °C overnight. The obtained mixture was collected into a covered cauldron and heated at 560 °C for 4 h. After that, the catalyst was successful prepared and denoted as CC1@mCN10. CC1@mCNx photocatalysts were prepared by the same process of CC1@mCN10, in which x = 3, 5, 7, 15, or 20 represents the gram of the melamine dosages.

All the transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Fourier infrared (FT-IR) spectra, X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns, BET surface areas, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrum (UV–vis DRS), photoluminescence (PL) spectra, ESR spectroscopy, ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) and other characterizations were same with the previously reported methods with some modification [4], and the details were added into the supplementary material.

Typically, 100 mg of xylose and a certain amount of photocatalysts were added into the reaction mixture with different concentrations of KOH. The obtained mixed system was firstly stirred in dark condition for 30 min. After that, the system was carried out at different reaction temperatures in the irradiation of visible light. After the reaction was completed, the samples were filtrated with millipore filter (0.22 µm) and then analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). Furthermore, xylose can be replaced by mannose, rhamnose, glucose, fructose and arabinose under optimum experimental conditions to investigate the universality of the photocatalytic system.

ce:section.ce:para: 100 mg of xylose and 40 mg of photocatalyst were added into 10 mL of KOH (2 M). The obtained reaction system was stirred in the dark for 30 min and then irradiated by visible light at 60 °C for 60 min. Subsequently, the photocatalysts were centrifuged and washed several times. The washed catalysts were dried overnight at 80 °C before reuse. Meanwhile, the samples were filtrated with millipore filter (0.22 µm) and detected by HPLC.

Typically, 100 mg of xylose and 40 mg of photocatalysts as well as an appropriate amount of sacrificial agent (e.g., ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid, tryptophan, p-benzoquinone and isopropyl) were added into 10 mL of KOH solution (2 M). Similarly, the series of mixed systems was firstly stirred in dark conditions for 30 min, and then performed at 60 °C for 60 min in the irradiation of visible light. After that, the conversion of xylose and the yield of lactic acid were detected by HPLC.

In this work, the reaction conditions were similar with that the above optimization conditions. The difference is that the light source was changed from visible light to sunlight, and the reaction temperature was changed from 60 °C to room temperature (~20 °C). Typically, 100 g of xylose and 40 g of catalysts were added into 10 L of KOH solution (2 M). The system was firstly stirred in the dark for 30 min and then performed at room temperature in the presence of sunlight. Finally, the lactic acid yield was detected by HPLC.

The obtained liquid samples were filtrated by millipore filter (0.22 µm) and then detected by HPLC with a Bio-Rad Aminex HPX-87H column (300 mm × 7.8 mm × 9 µm). The mobile phase was 5 mmol H2SO4 at a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min. The temperature of column was 40 °C. Fig. 1A displays the preparation process of CC1@mCNx photocatalysts. Initially, a certain amount of melamine and choline chloride was added to 50 mL of ultrapure water in a 250 mL beaker under vigorously stirring. Afterwards, the solution was stirred for 10 min and dried at 60 °C overnight. The obtained mixture was collected and calcinated at 560 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 for 4 h. Initially, the morphology and microstructure of the obtained photocatalysts were investigated by SEM and TEM. Fig. 1B shows that the carbon nitride (CN) obtained in this work without addition of choline chloride exhibits an irregular bulk structure, which is similar to that reported in a previous study [4]. When a certain amount of choline chloride was added in the preparation of the photocatalysts, the morphology of the obtained CC1@mCNx showed obvious changes. As shown in Figs. 1C, 1D and S1, the fluffy coral shapes of the CC1@mCN5, CC1@mCN10 and CC1@mCN15 were observed. Interestingly, with an increase in the amount of added choline chloride, increasing numbers of folds were formed on the surface of the CC1@mCNx. Furthermore, only the C, N and O elements were observed in the obtained photocatalyst (Fig. 1E-G), indicating that the C/N ratio in CC1@mCNx was changed as compared with CN. Similarly, the SEM energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) result indicated that the photocatalyst owns C (35.53 wt%), N (60.21 wt%) and O (4.26 wt%) elements (Fig. 1H). To further investigate the C/N ratio, elemental analysis was performed, and the results are given in Fig. 1I. Interestingly, the C/N ratio increased with a raise in choline chloride in the preparation of CC1@mCNx, which could change the photoelectric characteristics of these materials. Furthermore, the TEM results in Figs. 1J and 1K show the typical structures of CN and CC1@mCNx, respectively, which are consistent with the above SEM results.

It is widely accepted that modification of the morphology and element content will lead to the changes in the surface area and pore size, which will influence the adsorption and mass transfer performance of the reactants or products. Here, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area and pore size distribution were investigated. As shown in Fig. 2A, both CN and CC1@mCN10 presented type Ⅳ isotherms and H3 hysteresis loops, suggesting that both have a mesoporous structure. Furthermore, the BJH pore size distribution of the CN and CC1@mCN10 was similar, at 20–50 nm (Fig. 2B). However, the BET surface area of the CC1@mCN10 increased 8% as compared with that of the CN, suggesting that the CC1@CN10 is more conducive to adsorption and mass transfer of reactants or products.

To explore the crystal structures and chemical features, XRD and FT-IR spectroscopy were performed. As shown in Fig. 2C, only two diffraction peaks at 12.5° and 27.5° were observed, which were indexed to the (100) and (002) lattice planes, respectively. Here, the (100) peak corresponds to the tri-s-triazine units of in-plane repeating structural units, whereas the (002) plane represents the typical inter-planar stacking of conjugated aromatic sheets. Interestingly, the (100) peak gradually weakened with an increase in the addition of choline chloride, which suggests loss or change in the ordered structures within the CC1@mCMx framework as compared with CN. Furthermore, the (002) planes shifted to lower angles, indicating a reduced planar size of the layers and increased interlayer spacing [28]. Fig. 2D displays the FT-IR results of CN and CC1@mCNx, all of which appear to be similar and present a typical IR pattern of g-C3N4. The broad peak located at 3440 cm−1 belongs to the stretching vibration of N-H or O-H bonds of absorbed water [29]. The peaks near the 1200–1700 cm−1 region are related to the stretching vibration of heterocyclic CN [30]. The sharp peak at 810 cm−1 corresponds to the characteristic breathing vibration of tri-s-triazine ring units [31].

As shown in Fig. 3, the XPS results presented the chemical composition and status of the elements of CN and CC1@mCN10. Initially, the survey spectra showed that only C, N and O elements existed in the CN and CC1@mCN10 at contents of 43.13%/49.38%, 55.11%/47.94% and 1.76%/2.68%, respectively (Fig. 3A). As shown in Fig. 3B, three peaks located at 284.80, 286.02 and 288.30 eV were observed in the C 1s XPS spectra of CN and CC1@mCN10, which are attributed to the C-C, C-N and N-CN, respectively [32,33]. As compared with CN, the peak area of N-CN in the CC1@mCN10 decreased yet the C-N and C-C increased, which corresponds to the change in element content. In the N 1s XPS spectra, the amino groups (C-N-H, 401.35 eV), tertiary nitrogen (N-(C)3, 400.17 eV) and sp2-hybridized aromatic N atoms (C-NC, 398.79 eV) were observed (Fig. 3C) [34,35]. Apparently, the intensity of the N-(C)3 peak increased with addition of choline chloride. All of the results indicated that the content of the C element increased, resulting in a larger C/N ratio. Furthermore, two main peaks were observed at 532.25 eV and 533.57 eV (Fig. 3D). The first peak agrees well with C-O, which could be from the adsorbed CO2 or incompletely reacted oxygen-containing intermediates produced during the pyrolysis of melamine. The second was ascribed to the chemisorbed H2O [36].

To explore the visible light absorption ability of CN and CC1@mCNx, UV–vis DRS was performed. As shown in Fig. 4A, obvious red-shifting of the visible light absorption edge was observed as the choline chloride addition increased in the preparation of CC1@mCNx. These and the aforementioned results indicate that an increase in the C/N ratio causes the visible light absorption range of the photocatalyst to increase, corresponding to a decrease in bandgap from 2.8 eV to 2.2 eV (Fig. 4B). The reason for this phenomenon might be that the adjustment of the C/N ratio changed the electronic arrangement of the material itself. To investigate the separation rate of photogenerated carriers, photoluminescence (PL) spectroscopy was performed. As shown in Fig. 4C, the PL intensity of the series of CC1@mCNx was lower than that of CN, indicating that higher charge separation and lower recombination were achieved, thereby resulting in enhanced photocatalytic activity. This phenomenon might have been caused by the change in C/N ratio, which improved the transmissions e- and h+ [37]. Furthermore, photocurrent responses were also performed to investigate the separation efficiency of the photogenerated charge carriers. As depicted in Fig. S2, the CC1@mCN10 had a larger photocurrent value than the CN. The higher photocurrent density indicates higher separation efficiency of the photogenerated charge carriers and that more electrons will be involved in the reaction [38,39]. Moreover, the electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) Nyquist plots of CN and CC1@mCN10 were also explored in the irradiation of visible light. As shown in Fig. 4D, the diameter of the semicircle for CC1@mCN10 was smaller than that of CN, suggesting that a lower charge transfer resistance was achieved in CC1@mCN10 [40,41]. All the above results indicated that the change in C/N ratio caused a larger visible light adsorption range in the CC1@mCNx and faster e--h+ transmission, resulting in enhanced photocatalytic activity.

The valence band maximum and work function are important for evaluating the photocatalytic performance of the obtained photocatalysts [41]. Here, all of them towards CN and CC1@mCN10 were investigated by UPS analysis, and the results are given in Fig. 5. Apparently, the high binding energy cutoff regions (Ecutoff) were 15.80 eV and 15.20 eV for CN and CC1@mCN10, respectively. Correspondingly, the low binding energy portions (Eedge) of the UPS spectra were +0.42 and −0.48 eV for CN and CC1@mCN10, respectively. The work functions (Ф) were calculated to be 5.42 eV and 6.02 eV versus vacuum, respectively, by using Eq. (1) [42]. Similarly, the EVB obtained from Eq. (2) for CN and CC1@mCN10 were 5.84 and 5.54 eV versus vacuum [42]. On the basis of the relationship between the vacuum energy (Eabs) and the normal electrode potential (Eϴ), Eabs = -Eϴ - 4.44 eV, the EVB were calculated to be 1.4 eV and 1.1 eV versus the normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) for CN and CC1 @mCN10, respectively.

Obviously, the slopes of CN and CC1@mCN10 are positive (Figs. 5C, S3, S4), suggesting that they are all n-type semiconductors [43]. It is widely accepted that the flat band potential of n-type semiconductors is close to the conduction band potential, whereas the flat band potential of p-type semiconductors is near the valance band potential [44]. On the basis of the above analysis, the ECB for CN and CC1@mCN10 were −1.4 V and −1.3 versus NHE. Thus, the relative band alignment of CN and CC1@mCN10 was obtained (Fig. 5D).

The photocatalytic activities of CN and CC1@mCNx were investigated by photocatalytic reforming of biomass-derived monosaccharides to lactic acid. Initially, a series of experiments with xylose (100 mg) and photocatalysts (50 mg) as well as KOH solution (10 mL, 1 M) was performed at 40 °C for 30 min in the irradiation of visible light. Interestingly, the yield of lactic acid firstly increased with an enhancement of the C/N ratio and then decreased, in which the CC1@mCN10 showed the best photocatalytic performance (46.23%) (Fig. S5). In combination of the above characterization of CN and CC1@mCNx, the results indicate that proper identification of the visible light absorption region and separation rate of photogenerated carriers is beneficial for the formation of lactic acid during these processes. In the following experiments, the effects of different reaction conditions on the synthesis of lactic acid photocatalyzed by CC1@mCN10 were investigated. It is widely accepted that, the pH value of the reaction system is an important factor in selective conversion of biomass. In this study, a series of experiments was conducted at 50 °C for 60 min with various concentrations of KOH solution. As shown in Fig. 6A, the yield of lactic acid increased obviously from 17.20% to 66.19% when the KOH concentration increased from 0.1 M to 2.0 M. With further improvement in the KOH concentration, the lactic acid yield decreased. This could be attributed to the increase in the content of active oxygen species with the increase in alkali concentration, resulting in peroxidation of the lactic acid. During these processes, the conversion of xylose was raised with the increased KOH concentration, and a series of by-products such as glyceraldehyde, formic acid and acetic acid was observed. Furthermore, the reaction temperature plays a major role in the conversion of carbohydrates, which can affect their selectivity. Thus, the influences of different reaction temperatures on the selective oxidation of xylose to lactic acid were explored. Obviously, an increase in reaction temperature is beneficial for the synthesis of lactic acid, although the results do not continue to improve with further increases in temperature (Fig. 6B). This might be explained by the side reaction caused by higher temperature. The highest lactic acid yield achieved 74.97% at 60 °C. With the increase in reaction temperature, the conversion of xylose continuously improved (Fig. 6B). Similarly, glyceraldehyde, formic acid and acetic acid were also detected during these processes (Fig. 6B).

Next, the effects of the catalyst dosages on the photo-reforming of xylose to lactic acid were evaluated, and the results are given in Fig. 6C. The yield of lactic acid firstly increased and then decreased with an increase in CC1@mCN10 dosage. This phenomenon could be attributed to the formation of unstable compounds on the surface of the catalyst with an increase in the solid-liquid ratio, which leads to a decrease in activation energy in the entire reaction system. Interestingly, the xylose was completely converted during these processes. Furthermore, the by-products of formic acid, acetic acid and glyceraldehyde were detected during these systems, although their yields did not change regularly (Fig. 6C). Lastly, the effects of visible light irradiation time on the lactic acid formation from xylose was explored. Apparently, the yield of lactic acid increased with prolonged irradiation time (Fig. 6D). When the irradiation time exceeded 60 min, the lactic acid yield began to decrease (Fig. 6D). The conversion of xylose increased with prolonged visible light and achieved 100% at 60 min (Fig. 6D). Similarly, the by-products of glyceraldehyde, formic acid and acetic acid were also detected in these systems.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The recycling stability and universality of CC1@mCN10
ce:section.ce:para: The catalytic stability of CC1@mCN10 was also investigated. Typically, the reaction with 100 mg of xylose and 10 mL of KOH solution (2.0 M) as well as 40 mg of CC1@mCN10 was performed at 60 °C for 60 min in the presence of visible light. When the photocatalyst was used for the ninth time, the yield of lactic acid was 86.4% of that obtained the first time, and the conversion of xylose remained stable at 100% ( Fig. 7A). This result indicates that CC1@mCN10 has excellent stability on the synthesis of lactic acid from xylose. Furthermore, for evaluating the catalyst, its universality is an important index. Here, the universality of CC1@mCN10 was explored by synthesis of lactic acid from different biomass-derived monosaccharides, and the results are given in Fig. 7B. Interestingly, the conversions of all biomass-derived pentoses and hexoses were 100%, whereas the yields of lactic acid from xylose, glucose, fructose, rhamnose, mannose and arabinose were 76.82%, 69.90%, 57.46%, 50.96%, 64.13% and 79.82%, respectively (Fig. 7B). This phenomenon indicates that CC1@mCN10 presents excellent photocatalytic university for the synthesis of lactic acid from biomass-derived monosaccharides.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The comparison of the effects of CC1@mCN10 and different reported systems on the synthesis of lactic acid
ce:section.ce:para: To gain a better understanding of the CC1@mCN10 photocatalytic system, a series of previously reported photocatalytic systems is listed here [3–5,15,27,45–47]. Apparently, regardless of whether the substrates were xylose or glucose, the thermal catalytic processes for the synthesis of lactic acid required high temperatures (e.g., 140 °C [47], 170 °C [15,27], 200 °C [45]) and high pressures (e.g., 4 MPa [45], 15 bar N2 [27]) or long reaction times (e.g., 160 min [27], 240 min [15], 300 min [46,47]) as compared with this work (60 °C, 60 min) (Table S1, entries 1, 3, 4, 5 and 9). More interestingly, the lactic acid yield (76.82%) obtained in this work was higher than that of previously reported thermal catalytic systems [5,27,45,47]. The photocatalytic reforming of biomass-derived sugars to lactic acid via B@mCN, [5] Ut-OCN [5], CuO@CS-H [3], and Zn1−xCdx [46] reported in our previously reports showed a similar performance as compared with CC1@mCN10 (Table S1, entries 1, 2, 6 and 7). However, the preparation process of CC1@mCN10 is simple and economical. In brief, CC1@mCN10 is an efficient, economic and environmentally friendly photocatalyst for the reforming of biomass-derived sugars to lactic acid.

To illustrate the application potential of CC1@mCN10 in the industrial production of lactic acid, a 1000-fold scale-up experiment was performed. Here, the dosages of xylose and CC1@mCN10 as well as the volume of KOH solution (2.0 M) were changed to 1000-fold as compared the optimal reaction conditions during the aforementioned experiment. The differences were that the light source was changed from visible light to sunlight and the reaction temperature was maintained at room temperature (~20 °C). Once the reaction was complete, the product was analyzed via high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). The yield of lactic acid was 48.3%, which is higher than under similar reaction conditions. Combined with the economic benefits as well as the efficiency and environmental friendliness of the entire reaction system, the photocatalytic reforming of biomass-derived sugars process via CC1@mCN10 has potential for industrial production of lactic acid.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The production of various oxidation active species and their influences on the synthesis of lactic acid
ce:section.ce:para: To address the possible reaction mechanism of photocatalytic reforming of xylose to lactic acid, electron paramagnetic resonance (ESR) spin trapping was performed. Here, the 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl (TEMPO) was used to trap e- and h+. Interestingly, a triple peak in the ESR spectrum with an intensity of 1:1:1 was observed in dark conditions with CN or CC1@mCN10 or in the visible light irradiation conditions without photocatalysts (Fig. S6). Once the TEMPO was added to the visible light irradiation system with CN or CC1@mCN10, the signal intensity of e- decreased with an increase in irradiation time, indicating that more e- was generated (Fig. S7, S8). More interestingly, lower signal intensity was presented in the CC1@mCN10 system as compared with CN, suggesting that more e- was produced in the CC1@mCN10. As is known, the e- and h+ appear in pairs, so the change rule of h+ is consistent with that of e-, although the change trend was slightly lower than that of e- (Figs. S9, S10, 8A). Furthermore, no ESR signals were observed in the·OH and·O2 - system, although once the DMPO was added in these systems, corresponding signals were presented ( Figs. 8B, 8C). For·OH, the adduct of DMPO/·OH presented a four-line spectrum with relative intensity of 1:2:2:1 (Fig. 8B). Obviously, the signal intensity of DMPO/·OH increased with prolonged visible light in the CN or CC1@mCN10 system (Fig. S11, S12). Interestingly, the ESR signal intensity of the CC1@mCN10 system was higher than that of CN, suggesting that more·OH was generated. Similarly, the ESR signal of the adduct DMPO/·O2 - also showed a similar change trend, in which the DMPO/·O2 - presented a four-line spectrum with relative intensity of 1:1:1:1 (Figs. S13, S14, 8C). Furthermore, 1O2 is in a special state of existence, which shows excellent selective oxidation. Similar to that of·OH and·O2 -, no ESR signal existed in the pure 1O2 system. Here, 2,2,6,6-etrarnethyl-4-piperldone-1-oxyl (TEMPONE) was used to detect the 1O2, resulting in a triple ESR spectrum with intensity of 1:1:1. Interestingly, the signal intensity increased with the increase in visible-light irradiation in the CN or CC1@mCN10 system, resulting in more 1O2 produced (Figs. S15, S16, 8D). More interestingly, the signal intensity observed in the CC1@mCN10 system was higher than that of the CN system, suggesting that more 1O2 was generated under the same conditions (Fig. 8D).

ce:section.ce:section-title: The possible mechanism for the conversion of xylose photocatalyzed by CC1@mCN10
ce:section.ce:para: As discussed above, the active oxygen species of h+,·OH,·O2 - and 1O2 were detected in the CC1@mCN10 photocatalytic system. Here, the effects of different active oxygen species on the synthesis of lactic acid from xylose photocatalyzed by CC1@mCN10 were investigated, and the results are given in Fig. 9. When the isopropyl (IPA), tryptophan (Trp), ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), and benzoquinone (BQ) were added to the series of the reaction systems, no obvious change was observed on the conversion of xylose, whereas the yield of lactic acid decreased in turn as compared with the system of no added sacrificial agent (Fig. 9). These results indicate that all·OH, 1O2, h+ and·O2 - are beneficial for the synthesis of lactic acid, of which the·O2 - plays a major role.

On the basis of the above analysis and the experimental results [48–50], a possible reaction pathway for the photocatalytic reforming of xylose is proposed. As shown in Fig. 10, e- and h+ appeared in pairs in the irradiation of visible light, and the h+ was then reacted with OH- to generate·OH. Similarly, the e- met the O2 to form·O2 -. Furthermore, the obtained·O2 - can also react with h+ to generate 1O2 [4]. Afterwards, xylose was converted to xylulose via isomerisation under the CC1@mCN10 system, and glyceraldehyde and dihydroxyacetone were then obtained from xylulose by retro-aldol. The lactic acid was produced from glyceraldehyde. However, the pyruvaldehyde was produced from dihydroxyacetone via dehydration and was then directly converted to lactic acid. Furthermore, xylonic acid was produced from xylose via selective oxidation, which can be converted to formic acid via α-oxidation or β-oxidation.

In summary, a series of fluffy coral-shaped and metal-free CC1@mCNx photocatalysts was prepared via a novel strategy of dissolution-drying-calcination. The increased C/N ratio in the CC1@mCNx significantly extended the visible light adsorption range and decreased the PL intensity. The experimental results indicated that proper visible light absorption region and separation rate of photogenerated carriers were beneficial for the formation of lactic acid during these processes, in which stronger parameters do not yield better results. The lactic acid yield was 76.82% via CC1@mCN10, in which the CC1@mCN10 shows excellent stability and reusability. Furthermore, the CC1@mCN10 reaction system has excellent university for the synthesis of lactic acid from biomass-derived monosaccharides. The·OH, 1O2, h+ and·O2 - were all beneficial in the lactic acid formation, in which the·O2 - plays a major role. The results of 1000-fold scale-up experiments combined with the simple, efficient and economical catalyst preparation process indicate that the system has potential for industrial production of lactic acid.
